p: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is the most common causative agent of acute viral hepatitis. Eight HEV genotypes (HEV-1 to HEV-8) have been described, of which five are well recognized as human pathogens ( 1). HEV-1 and HEV-2 are waterborne, transmitted through fecal-oral routes, and are responsible for large HEV outbreaks in resource-limited countries. HEV-3 and HEV-4 are linked to zoonotic transmission and cause sporadic infections in industrialized countries. It has been reported that HEV subtype 1e (HEV-1e) was responsible for a large outbreak in sub-Saharan Africa (Chad). The T3 strain (GenBank accession no. AY204877) was obtained from an infected person from France during an outbreak in Chad in 1983 and represents the only complete genome sequence of HEV-1e available ( 2). We report the second full-length genome sequence of an HEV-1e strain (NG/17-0503) from a recent outbreak in Nigeria in 2017. The virus was isolated from a 35-year-old resident of the Mobbar local government area of Borno State, Nigeria. The patientâ€™s serum tested positive for HEV antibodies using Wantai HEV IgM rapid test and Wantai HEV IgM enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA; Sanbio, The Netherlands).
